description: From Dutch kielhalen (“keelhaul”), from kiel (“keel”) + halen (“fetch; catch”).

verbs.description: keelhaul (third-person singular simple present keelhauls, present participle keelhauling, simple past and past participle keelhauled)

entries.meaning: (transitive, nautical) To punish by dragging under the keel of a ship.

examples: I've been asking myself the same question and there are two ways to answer it—yes and no. Yes, because he took on a responsibility no one else wanted—for the reasons we've all witnessed—and no because keelhauling him will be five percent about fixing what he may have done wrong and ninety-five percent about scapegoating.
